It is assumed that fishes used for stomach content analysis were collected by the charter boat sports fishery in the Gulf of Mexico north of Tampa, but specifically around Panama City and Destin, FL. This is the location of the king mackerel fishery from May to October, which is the time period (spring and summer) that the author indicates the stomachs were collected.

GEAR_NOTES: 20 foot, 60 foot and 100 foot bag seine

Fishes were collected from the Clear Lake area and its tributaries with a 3m otter  trawl. A 6mm bar mesh cover was used over the cod end or the trawl during some of the sampling to capture post larval fish, many of which were less than 15mm in length. The larger bar of mesh of the trawl  19mm and 13 mm in the body and length . The larger bar of mesh of trawl, 19 mm and 13mm in the body and cod end, respectively, permitted many of the smaller fish to escape when the cover was not used.

Fishes were collected from the Clear Lake area and its tributaries with a 3m otter  trawl. A 6mm bar mesh cover was used over the cod end or the trawl during some of the sampling to capture post larval fish, many of which were less than 15mm in length. The larger bar of mesh of the trawl  19mm and 13 mm in the body and length . The larger bar of mesh of trawl, 19 mm and 13mm in the body and cod end, respectively, permitted many of the smaller fish to escape when the cover was not used.
600 feet by 4 feet deep of 2 1/2 stretch mesh nets were used to collect fish for tagging.
COLL_NOTES: The "strike" method used for obtaining fish.

Trawling times varied from 10 minutes to 2 hours depending on the depth and bottom conditions. Most tows were for 30 minutes. 98 bottom trawl samples were taken in 1970, 84 in 1971, 118 in 1972. From June 1973 to January 1974, 36 trawl samples were taken in areas where a shrimp fleet was working. In June, July and August 1974, 45 samples were taken with the fleet. Trawling sampling depths ranged between 5.5 and 173.7 m. Field work was accomplished from aboard the Texas Parks and Wildlife vessel Western Gulf. An attempt was made to take samples at 9.1 m intervals each month, with supplementary sampling as time allowed. The majority of collections were obtained between 7.3 and 64.0 m off shore of Port Aransas and Freeport-Galveston.

Field work was conducted from a small outboard boat. A systematic sampling survey, consisting of several passes through the 2m wide study transect, was made on eight occasions between August, 1970 and July, 1971. Studies on food habits of the red snapper, Lutjanus campechanus (Poey), were conducted by James K. Davis concurrently with the present study.

GEAR_NOTES: Two 25m nets were deployed in sequence between transects. Nets were set on three successive days at 1730 then checked at 2030 and again at midnight for both crepuscular and nocturnal predators.
Two 25m nets were deployed in sequence between transects. Nets were set on three successive days at 1730 then checked at 2030 and again at midnight for both crepuscular and nocturnal predators.
3 types: angular wooden, square wooden, heart shaped wire
3 types: angular wooden, square wooden, heart shaped wire

12.2 m semi-baloon trawl having a 12.2 m float line and a 13.8 m lead line. The trawl was constructed of 47.6 mm stretched mesh, untreated nylon (#18 twine) throughout the body and 38.1 m stretched mesh nylon (#30 twine) in the cod end. Untreated nylon webbing prevented contamination of samples taken for hydrocarbon analysis. A 2/O galvanizxed "tickler" chain was attached to the 2.4 x 1.0 m mahogany trawl doors to enhance capture of demersal organisms.
COLL_NOTES: Three 20-min trawl tows were made at each station. Trawls were towed at a vessel speed of approximately 2 knots along one or more sides of a triangle formed by three bouys marking the station. Trawls were towed at night to minimize net avoidance.
FIELD_PRES_NOTES: sorted finfish collections weighing less than 9 kg were placed in plastic bags, properly labeled and quick frozen.

GEAR_NOTES: Consisting of nine 500 µm mesh nets with a smaller 67 µm mesh net nested inside each.
COLL_NOTES: Samples were taken at discrete depths in the upper mixed layer and were pooled with Bongo net samples. Samples were taken every 6 h, pooled according to net size, concentrated by screening, and frozen.
Samples taken obliquely from near bottom to surface. Samples were taken every 6 h, pooled according to net size, concentrated by screening, and frozen.
Sampled dockside at Johns Pass , Pinellas County, FL. Aperiodic sampling was carried out from May 1978 to July 1992

GEAR_NOTES: One hour tow with 65 foot trawl with 2 inch strech mesh at depths ranging from 7 to 39 fathoms.
COLL_NOTES: R/V Oregon (Cruise 90) - off LA coast Feb. and Mar. 1964.
DIET_ANALYSIS_METHODS: Stomach contents were analyzed and the volume of each different food item was measured by displacement of water in a graduated cylinder. Excess fluid was blotted from the food material, before the volumetric measurements were made.

GEAR_NOTES: A series of three No. 7 "curved point" tuna hooks were used on each handline, with lead weights varying from 1 to 8 pounds, depending on the current speed.

GEAR_NOTES: Lines of dredging and fishing stations ran across plateau in an E and W direction at 10 miles intervals.
Trials were made at each dredging station generally in 5-10 minutes intervals btween stations during the daytime.

COLL_NOTES: In fishing, baited hooks are suspended approximately one to three feet above the sea floor. Once a fish is caught and hauled onto the deck, it is unhooked by inserting a short pole into the gape and allowing the line to coil around it. A sudden thrust extracts the hook. The fish are drawn, but the viscera and the blood are not always entirelyremoved or is the fish rinsed off properly.
FIELD_PRES_NOTES: Icing takes place within 2 hours of the time the fish are caught. The fish are placed on ice with their drawn sides down, to permit drainage. Ice separates each layer of fish; the top layer is more hevily iced.

Icing takes place within 2 hours of the time the fish are caught. The fish are placed on ice with their drawn sides down, to permit drainage. Ice separates each layer of fish; the top layer is more hevily iced.

GEAR_NOTES: Line fishing was conducted using electric reels and a range of hook sizes (#2 through 4/0 Mustad hooks). Terminal tackle consisted of lead weights (250 to 907 g) and two or three hooks baited with squid. Hook and line fishing was concentrated during the bours between 1900 and 0200, although collections were made on all cruises during most hours of the day.
COLL_NOTES: Sampling was conducted aboard research vessels during eight seasonal (winter, January; spring, April/May; summer, July/August; and fall, Oct/Nov) criuses between October 1980 and October 1982. Fish were weighed (g) and measured (mm fork length: FL) upon capture. The position and depth of all collecting stations and time of capture was recorded.
FIELD_PRES_NOTES: rinsed in running water and blotted dry prior to examination
LAB_PRES_NOTES: Partially digested fish prey were cleared with trypsin and stained with alcian blue and alizarin red so that meristic counts could be used for identification.
DIET_ANALYSIS_METHODS: The contents of stomachs and intestines (excluding caecum) were placed in separate bowls and examined with a binocular microscope equipped with an ocular micrometer. Individual prey items were identified to lowest taxon possible, counted, and measured along their greatest extent.

GEAR_NOTES: Paired 25 m monofilament gill nets (75 cm2 stretch mesh) were occasionally used on the reefs. Gill nets were placed early in the evening and retrieved the following day.

Regular otter trawl net as is used in the shrimp fishery, except it was somewhat smaller. It had a wingspread of 30ft at the mouth and a mesh of 1 1/2 in stretched. A total of 109 hauls in 3 locations.
Net was 1200 ft long and was used with the net skiff.  The depth of the net was 4 ft. The mesh was 1 3/4 in stretched. A total of 114 hauls in 2 locations.
Seine was 300 ft in length. The mesh was 2 in stretched and the depth of the net was 3 ft. A total of 23 seins made.
3 different seines - 1) A 3m, 4.3mm mesh, straight seine;  2) A 10.7m, 12.7mm mesh bag seine; 3) A 45.7m, 12.7mm bag seine
3 different trawls - 1) a 4.9m, 19.1mm mesh trawl; 2) a 2.4m, 19.1mm mesh trawl; 3) a 9.1m, 19.1mm mesh trawl. Trawling speed was a constant 2000 rpm and duration was 0.5 hr.

set at 5 stations (1, 4, 6, 8, 10) around the lake. 2 types used - 1)91.4m gill net, 1.8m deep, made up of 4, 22.85m sections. Mesh sizes were (bar measurment) 25.4mm, 50.8mm, 76.2mm, and 101.6mm.  2) a 91.4m, 1.8m deep trammel net. Inner net mesh was 38.1mm, outer mesh was 254mm. Set for a standard period of 240 min (4 hr).

an aluminum bateau with a gas-powered D.C. generator was used at certain areas of the marsh stations to supplement the regular collections in an attempt to overcome some of the adverse conditions that made the normal techniques inadequate.

A standard otter trawl with a 10-ft opening. The otter boards were 10x24 inches in size. The wings of the trawl net were netting with a mesh size of 7/8 in on the side or 1 3/4 in stretched measure. The cod end was made of heavy twine with a mesh size of 1/2 in on the side or 1 in stretched. An inner liner was inserted inside the cod end. The mesh of the liner measured 3/16 in on the side or 3/8 in stretched. Trawl tows were made both in straight lines and in circles and were timed to 10 min duration.
Seine net had a mesh size of 3/8 in on the side or 3/4 in stretched. Seining started at a depth of approx. 4 ft, stretched parallel to shore and pulled straight in.
Net was 20 ft. The mesh was 1/4 in on the side or 1/2 in stretched.

Trammel net was 1200 ft long.2 methods used: playing the net out of a skiff parallel to shore then creating a disturbance to cause fish to swim into net. Method 2: "cork-screwing" the net - playing the net out in a circle, leaving the end in the skiff. One person continues to pull the leading end of the net around at the same time decreasing the diameter of circle while helpers feed other end into the boat.
5-meter (1.9 cm mesh wing and body, 0.6 cm mesh liner). Seven 2min trawl-tows (at 2-3 knots) were taken at each station both day and night.
Larger fishes ( >3000 SL) were taken with a 100 meter nylon trammel net.
Tammel nets (1" mesh) set at depths ranging from 1/2 meters to slightly over 1 and a half meters in two areas and at a depth of 1/2 meter or less in the third area.
38 drags were done. Trawling time varied from 8 to 61 min, with 15 min as the usual time.

11 seines were conducted in the shallow water along the north shore of the lake.
20 drags done with a 22 ft. trawl, 3/4 in bar mesh with soc, 3/8 in bar mesh.  11 drags done with a 35 ft trawl, 3/4 in bar mesh. Trawling time varied from 8 to 30 min, with 15 min as the usual time.
11 seines were conducted in the shallow water along the north shore of the lake.
Surface trawl - airboat pulled a net with a body mesh of 0.6cm (bar) and knitted circular cod mesh of 0.3cm (diameter), between two stakes set 400m apart in each of the eight ponds.
Bottom trawl - airboat pulled a 7.6m otter trawl with body mesh of 1.6cm (bar) and cod mesh of 1.4cm (bar) along the same transects as the surfac e trawl.
